trial_identification.studytitle: Time series RNA-sequence analysis of Tulsi herbal tea effects on mood, cognitive health and metabolic function
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Time series transcriptome analysis of Tulsi effects on mood, cognitive health and metabolic function
trial_identification.trialacronym: TTRACE (Tulsi Time-series RNA-seq Analysis of Cognition & Emotion)

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal metabolism and endocrine development and function
Studies of the normal brain and nervous system

interventions.interventions:
This is a preliminary randomized placebo-controlled cross-over study comparing the time course of changes in mood, cognitive health and metabolic function after a single dose of 250ml tulsi tea (hot to warm) and 250ml filtered water (room temperature).
The interventions will be either Tulsi herbal tea 2g standardized commercial grade tea bag steeped in 250ml filtered warm-hot water or Placebo filtered room temp water 250ml.
Participants will receive the two interventions as a beverage on two separate occasions in a randomized crossover sequence with a minimum of 48 hours washout. Doses will be administered by healthcare professionals at the study site.
interventions.comparator: Comparator/control will be 250ml of room temperature filtered water

primaryOutcome.outcome:
Whole blood transcriptome will be analysed using microarray analysis at baseline and the change in expression from baseline to time intervals after administration of the intervention.
This preliminary analysis is to identify the time point that expression profiles start to change post intervention
primaryOutcome.timepoint: at baseline (before intervention), after 30min, 60min and 90 min post intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Measurement of the Mood states using a Profile of Mood States (POMS) questionnaire consisting of 65-adjectives that participants will rate the level (1-5 scale) at which they have been feeling before the drink, 30minutes, 60minutes and 90 minutes after the consumption of the drink.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: at baseline (before intervention), after 30min, 60min and 90 min post intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Cognitive Function assessed using CogState computerized battery

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: -aged between 18 and 60 years, English speaking and able to give written informed consent -non-smokers - willing to avoid caffeine-containing drinks, alcohol and prescription medications for 24 hours prior to the testing sessions
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: The exclusion criteria are designed to exclude confounding factors that may impact on cognitive, physiological or metabolic function. People with be excluded if they are: - Smokers -regular coffee drinkers - regular consumers of herbal extracts or tulsi tea - Have known allergies to basil or herbal tea - Have diabetes or a severe chronic infection or illness that may impact on the outcome measures such as current or previous history of renal, cardiac, gastrointestinal, liver or psychiatric disorders or pulmonary (other than either asthma not requiring continuous medication or sleep apnoea-related disorders), or any other condition that in the opinion of the investigators would impede competence, compliance, or participation in the study. -Taking blood thinner medication -pregnant or expect to be pregnant - Unable to give informed consent

trial_design.concealment: Allocation concealment is done in sealed opaque envelopes
trial_design.sequence: Participants are allocated to either active intervention or placebo using computerised sequence generation
trial_design.statisticalmethods: The Statistical Package for the Social Sciences software (SPSS Inc., Armonk, New York, USA) will be used for data analysis. As this is an exploratory pilot study using pooled data, no inferential statistical tests are proposed (data analysis will mainly involve descriptive statistics) and therefore it is not deemed necessary to conduct a formal power analysis.

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
Tulsi or Holy Basil is an Indian herb used for centuries for coping with stress as well as for the treatment of Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) and other metabolic disorders. Tulsi tea is widely available throughout the world as a caffeine free herbal tea with no reported side effects in literature associated with regular consumption of tulsi tea. Considerable evidence in animal models shows that tulsi improves cognition, immunity, stress and metabolic disorders. Also accumulating evidence from human trials indicate that long-term tulsi ingestion improves mood, cognition and metabolic function. However, there are no published reports on short term effects of tulsi on these pathways in humans. With the advancement in whole genome mRNA sequencing platform (transcriptome sequencing) a snapshot of RNA transcripts in a given sample can reveal much information on the regulation of different transcripts involved in metabolic pathways.
Therefore, next generation sequencing will provide an assessment of overall metabolic function at different time points in this study. This includes known gene transcripts that have been previously associated with metabolism and cognition, along with previously unknown gene transcripts that may be identified in our study.
While it likely that consumption of an herbal tea such as tulsi, which has previously been shown to influence metabolic function, will result in short term transcriptome changes and specifically cognitive function, the time course of these changes is uncertain.
This project aims to explore time course of transcriptome and cognitive function changes after the consumption of a single cup of tulsi tea in healthy individuals. This research is expected to provide preliminary evidence on the time course of any short-term effects of consuming a single cup of tulsi tea with possible insight into the molecular mechanisms involved in metabolic and cognitive pathways.
